page-0.title:
Scaling Down to Zero:
The Need to Reconsider Negative Emissions Technologies

page-1.text: Climate scientists agree: the earth is warming largely due to greenhouse gas emissions. Logically, the most important step is reducing emissions.  But one concern is dealing with historic emissions trapped in the atmosphere. (1/3)

page-2.text: In a race against the clock, climate governance is embracing a variety of geoengineering technologies to eliminate some of these emissions. However, given that these solutions aren’t being paired with meaningful fossil fuel reductions, they will most likely be used to justify continuing business-as-usual practices. (2/3)
page-2.hoverText: Geoengineering: To make a large-scale effort to modify the earth or its environment, especially to counteract global warming

page-3.text: This project looks at the nuances of one of these technologies called Bioenergy with Carbon Capture and Storage, or BECCS. So how does BECCS work? (3/3)

page-4.text: 'The idea is that, as it grows, biomass will continuously capture CO2 from the atmosphere. When the biomass is burned for energy, the waste CO2 will also be captured and stored underground, instead of being released back into the atmosphere. The assumption is that this will result in negative emission'(FOEI).

page-5.text: There are many flaws to this logic. For example, rather than planting a diverse forest ecosystem, usually one single fast growing tree species is planted (referred to as monoculture plantations) which require large amounts of land and high external inputs, including water and chemicals (Figueroa).

page-6.text: Even more, BECCS has hardly been tested.

page-7.text: One of the few existing BECCS projects in the world is the Decatur ethanol refinery, owned by the largest agribusiness in the world, The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company. Although it’s claimed to be ‘carbon negative’, the fact that it is powered by fossil fuels and uses corn (an energy-intensive crop) this is an inaccurate claim (Big Bad Fix).

page-8.text: In order to understand the degree to which BECCS is being proposed in future climate change policy, it’s helpful to first look at past emissions.

page-9.annotation: This graph represents global historic emissions of greenhouse gases, measured in gigatons (one gigaton = one billion tons).

page-10.annotation: Edison invents the central power station in 1882. At this time, global GHG emissions were nearing only 1 gigaton.

page-11.annotation: Emissions begin to rise. But not all emissions have been evenly produced; by 1970, the U.S. and U.K. were responsible for 75% of emissions worldwide.
page-11.hoverText: Given this stark statistic, the concept of 'Common But Differentiated Responsibility' emerged, recognizing the historical responsibility of industrialized countries for global environmental problems, and implying they take far-reaching measures in responding meaningfully to such problems (Walerius).

page-12.annotation: Today global emissions have reached more than 35 gigatons per year, and are projected to continue.

page-13.annotation: This accumulation of emissions corresponds to a rise in temperature of 1.16°C (2°F). If we compare this rise to body temperature, a 2°F increase signals a problem.

page-14.annotation: Now let’s look forward to possible future scenarios.

page-15.annotation: Absent any changes, temperatures are set to rise to at least 39°F above pre-industrial levels. This is referred to as the baseline scenario.

page-16.annotation: If all current climate mitigation policies are enforced, the trajectory would look something like this: where temperatures might rise by about 37°F.

page-17.annotation: Finally, there are scenarios that lead us to stay below a 35°F rise, corresponding to 1.5°C and 2°C, this is the threshold that climate scientists agree will help us to avoid unpredictable climate reactions.

page-18.annotation: One reason to be concerned about BECCS in particular is because it is one of the major players in these pathways. In fact of the 116 scenarios that would most likely keep global temperatures below 1.5 degrees, BECCS is included in 80% of them.

page-19.text:
So why should we be concerned about this?

One reason is the amount of resources BECCS would require. Let's look at how much land would be needed for the crop plantations and factories.

page-23.text: Another concern regarding BECCS is the fact that many fossil fuel companies are backing this technology. One concerning practice is called Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR). The liquid CO2 (produced by BECCS) is used to extract oil from a site that otherwise would not produce additional oil. [statistic about how 40% of co2 from one beccs site is already being used for that.

page-24.text: Additionally, BECCS models often don't account for the entire carbon lifecycle, let’s add in some of the missing emissions, many of which are unacknowledged in BECCS models.

page-25.text: Because industrial agriculture is required for BECCS, many additional emissions are released. In fact, industrial agriculture accounts for one-third of all global greenhouse gas emissions.

page-26.text: Einstein said that we can’t solve problems by using the same thinking that created them. In general, strategies like BECCS are problematic given that the same systems that are the main contributors to the current climate crisis are the ones that are producing these types of solutions. They often rely on a colonial concept of needing to ‘master’ nature. On the other hand, ‘Indigenous peoples have been doing safe and effective carbon dioxide removal while protecting biodiversity for centuries, without risky techno-fixes, conservation enclosures or market mechanisms, e.g., through community-based forest management’ (Figueroa).
